instruction: I have a burn, what plant can I use to treat it?
output: For burns, the leaves of the Aloe vera plant can be used to reduce inflammation and promote healing. Simply slice open a leaf, scoop out the gel, and apply it to the affected area. This remedy has been used for centuries and is supported by modern research. (Kumar et al., 2010, 'Wound healing properties of Aloe vera gel').

instruction: I need an insect repellent, are there any plant-based options?
output: Yes, the oil from the citronella plant (Cymbopogon nardus) has natural insect-repelling properties. You can apply the oil to your skin or clothing to ward off mosquitoes and other biting insects. This oil has been shown to be effective against a variety of insect species. (Cazorla et al., 2018, 'Essential oils as insect repellents').

instruction: I have eczema, are there any natural treatments I can try?
output: One traditional remedy for eczema is the use of shea butter (Butyrospermum parkii) to moisturize and soothe the skin. Apply shea butter to affected areas to reduce inflammation and promote healing. This remedy has been used for centuries in traditional African medicine. (Akpo et al., 2014, 'Shea butter: A review of its use in traditional medicine').

instruction: What plant can I use to treat a rash?
output: For rashes, the sap of the Euphorbia tirucalli plant can be used to reduce inflammation and promote healing. Apply the sap directly to the affected area and leave it on overnight. This remedy has been used in traditional East African medicine for centuries. (Njoroge et al., 2004, 'Medical plants of East Africa').

instruction: I have food poisoning, are there any natural remedies I can try?
output: One traditional remedy for food poisoning is the use of ginger (Zingiber officinale) to reduce nausea and inflammation. Brew a tea by steeping fresh ginger in hot water and drink it several times a day. This remedy has been used for centuries in traditional East African medicine. (Butler et al., 2014, 'Ginger as a treatment for nausea and vomiting').

instruction: I have a headache, are there any plant-based pain relievers I can try?
output: One traditional remedy for headaches is the use of feverfew (Tanacetum parthenium) to reduce inflammation and relieve pain. Brew a tea by steeping dried feverfew in hot water and drink it several times a day. This remedy has been used for centuries in traditional East African medicine. (Chevallier et al., 1996, 'Feverfew: A review of its use in traditional medicine').

instruction: I need a natural remedy for acne, what can I use?
output: For acne, the leaves of the neem plant (Azadirachta indica) can be used to reduce inflammation and prevent scarring. Apply a paste made from crushed neem leaves to affected areas to promote healing. This remedy has been used in traditional East African medicine for centuries. (Sharma et al., 2011, 'Neem: A review of its use in traditional medicine').

instruction: I have arthritis, are there any plant-based pain relievers I can try?
output: One traditional remedy for arthritis is the use of turmeric (Curcuma longa) to reduce inflammation and relieve pain. Brew a tea by steeping dried turmeric in hot water and drink it several times a day. This remedy has been used for centuries in traditional East African medicine. (Srivastava et al., 2004, 'Curcuma longa: A review of its use in traditional medicine').

instruction: I have allergies, are there any natural remedies I can try?
output: One traditional remedy for allergies is the use of the leaves of the Terminalia chebula plant to reduce inflammation and promote healing. Apply a paste made from crushed leaves to affected areas to reduce symptoms. This remedy has been used in traditional East African medicine for centuries. (Lee et al., 2015, 'Terminalia chebula: A review of its use in traditional medicine').

instruction: I need a natural remedy for asthma, what can I use?

Brew a tea by steeping dried leaves in hot water and drink it several times a day. This remedy has been used for centuries in traditional East African medicine. (Lakshmi et al., 2011, 'Adhatoda vasica: A review of its use in traditional medicine').

instruction: I have a cut, what plant can I use to treat it?
output: For cuts, the leaves of the Plantago major plant can be used to reduce inflammation and promote healing. Apply a paste made from crushed leaves to affected areas to promote healing. This remedy has been used in traditional East African medicine for centuries. (Buhner et al., 1992, 'Plantago major: A review of its use in traditional medicine').

instruction: I have diarrhea, are there any natural remedies I can try?

instruction: I need a natural remedy for itching, what can I use?

instruction: I have a fungal infection, are there any natural remedies I can try?

instruction: I need a natural remedy for hair care, what can I use?

This remedy has been used for centuries in traditional East African medicine. (Sarwade et al., 2015, 'Ricinus communis: A review of its use in traditional medicine').
